messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] giftedness
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 01/10/2001 1:25:27 AM !!!First Boot!!!, ... Yep. Nance
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 01/10/2001 1:25:27 AM !!!First Boot!!!,
amynelson3@... writes:


My point was just that maybe more kids would be allowed to explore their
true potential and more might be considered gifted if more were
homeschooled.


Amy




Yep.

Nance

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] giftedness
messages.msgSnippet: Oh, I definitely agree with you, Nance, and there will be some kids who are never considered gifted no matter how they are schooled. My point was just that
messages.messageBody:
Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] giftedness Oh, I definitely agree with you, Nance, and there will be some kids who are never considered gifted no matter how they are schooled. My point was just that maybe more kids would be allowed to explore their true potential and more might be considered gifted if more were homeschooled.

Amy
Mama to Accalia (6/14/99)
"The hardest to learn was the least complicated" -Indigo Girls

Some kids really are g/t and some aren't and there's no use comparing them
or denying either one exists.

imo

Nance

messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-dotcom] giftedness
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 01/09/2001 11:01:31 PM !!!First Boot!!!, ... There s probably some merit to this but, otoh, the reason some of us started hsing (and have
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 01/09/2001 11:01:31 PM !!!First Boot!!!,
amynelson3@... writes:


I think this
would be much more common if there were fewer kids who enjoyed learning and
were given the chance.





There's probably some merit to this but, otoh, the reason some of us started
hsing (and have ending up doing a sort of blended unschooling sort of on good
days and we'll see how things change over time!) is that the ps system was
unable to meet our gifted kids' needs.  We have discovered many other good
things about hsing, but g/t issues were the beginning of the problem with ps.
 Some kids really are g/t and some aren't and there's no use comparing them
or denying either one exists.

imo

Nance
